top_comment.text:
Stories like this is why I don't really consider myself a Humanist and why 
it never really grabbed me. IMHO stuff like this is the true nature of 
Humanity. If left to their own devices and with no real consequences for 
actions, this is what a large chunk of humans can bring themselves to do 
(or at least sit by and watch or not take action). Humans are animals. In 
every sense of the word. This is why we create things like Law, Ethics, 
Morality, etc. To keep these inner demons (whether to commit these 
atrocities or look the other way) that lurk in the depths of every human 
heart at bay. Even though our societies have gotten better (well, some 
have) over time it's not because Humanity is improving. It's because we're 
developing better systems, better laws and better philosophy. But I believe 
these base urges still remain underneath.﻿
top_comment.author: A86

comments.text:
+101andrewj - I'm convinced a lot of the problem is that Human technology 
has evolved far, far faster than Human morality/ethics. Our technology has 
grown but our hearts and minds haven't. Or are growing at a much slower 
rate. I think if something drastic were to happen in human society or 
civilization it might prompt us to finally start catching up our morals to 
our technology. Like if Climate Change or global economic depression were 
to finally start kicking our asses and making us reconsider our priorities.
comments.author: A86

comments.text:
+Christopher Jones - I agree. I guess I was more reacting to popular trends 
in Secular Humanism than the actual ideology itself. Unfortunately a lot of 
modern Humanists, since the Hippie Movement in the 60s, have adopted this 
view that Human nature is actually inherently benign and that our evil is 
all or mostly taught. I disagree with that view because many if not most of 
our evil tendencies shows clearly in infancy and early childhood without 
any evidence of having been taught to us. Such as our selfish crying, our 
disregard for the lives of others, our urges to destroy other life out of 
curiosity or amusement (kids killing bugs and birds), etc. 

I think it's only through intervention from ethical authority figures 
(parents, teachers, peers, counselors, etc.), constant external criticism, 
constant self-criticism and self-evaluation, and higher thought that we 
eventually partly free ourselves from these terrible natural passions. That 
and self-discipline and dedication to a higher universal code of ethics. I 
guess you could say I'm a modern-day Stoic in that sense.
comments.author: A86

comments.text:
its the 21st century and most humans cannot be trusted to carry around a 
sharp piece of steel with them because they might poke some other human 
with it, i seriously dont see us evolving to a point to where we are 
responsible enough to carry around nuclear reactors, if a certain amount of 
people with knives stab each other, whats a certain amount of people with 
anti matter space ships going to do, it just takes one bad apple to ruin 
the bunch, and never ever will the whole of humanity even be ready to carry 
a knife, so if our societies and cultures dont evolve, we are done for
comments.author: 101andrewj

comments.text:
I think you may be misunderstanding the term Humanist.  A Humanist 
(Humanism) refers to an intellectual state of mind; predominantly used to 
describe (secular) worldviews where one identifies with science having 
superior explanations for life and mankind (vs. supernatural notions). You 
could refer to it as a think tank for those acclimated to rational, 
empirically-arrived information.

The term humanitarian, or the "nature of Humanity," have different 
meanings, respectfully, at least in principle, if not more. But it is of 
course, all part of the human condition. And indeed, you are certainly 
correct with the "humans are mere animals" part, for better or worse. 
(Actually, we're unaware of any other species interested in deliberate 
genocide.)  The biological hardwiring (primordial to its core), is there 
"underneath" as you say. That's why we must come together and eradicate the 
primitivism.
comments.author: Christopher Jones

comments.text:
All of you are hyper emotional and retarded. Generally just not intelligent.

First of all you're reading too much into what I wrote, and going crazy 
with it.

The point I was making was Cenk often discloses how he feels about all 
these insane things that go down. Corruption, and this crazy shit in the 
video. But we can just keep it to this video, and how he was in total awe 
of this being a possibility in the world.

No one said a gun would automatically prevent something. That's a retarded 
assumption. So that handles most of your lame "derp derp these things can 
still happen!" Well they apparently do -- laws, police, guns, etc., they 
still happen. That's the point. lol...

But how is protecting you and your family responsibly with a gun, or 
attempting to do so with a gun -- because crazy people do in fact exist and 
aren't known by the police often --  then spoke about with this negative 
undertone?

It is logical for one to arm themselves if this is the shit that happens in 
the world. Whether you agree with it or not, it is a logical response to 
that awareness.

top_comment.text:
Not buying that Stanford experiment argument. You have to be a special kind 
of an evil bastard to commit these atrocities. ﻿
top_comment.author: acrh22

comments.text:
+Julie E
 Sorry, you are wasting my time here.
Acrh2 out.
comments.author: acrh22

comments.text:
You forgot quote number #3: "Not buying that Stanford experiment argument." 

No one is saying you claim to be an expert, that's the point - you're not. 
Stop requoting yourself like we lack the ability to read. I just asked you 
what's to "not buy" and the only on-topic response you've given is "because 
psychology is so far removed from physical science you take it's 
conclusions with a grain of salt."

Yes, psychology isn't a physical science - it's a social science. So is 
economics, anthropology, sociology, linguistics, and political science. Do 
you take all of those fields of study with a "grain of salt" as well? 

Bottom line, an experiment was conducted, the data was analyzed, and a 
conclusion was drawn. The experiment was then replicated, multiple times, 
with the same results. So why, as a scientist / chemist, one undoubtedly 
familiar with the scientific method,  would you choose to ignore the 
results?
comments.author: Julie E

comments.text:
+Dm Gray
Having a PhD in physical sciences makes more more of an expert in physical 
sciences than you or Julie.

At the same time, I never claimed to be an expert in psychology.

I only said, and I quote,
1) "But psychology itself, as a discipline, is so far removed from 
mainstream physical sciences, that I have to take any of its established 
conclusions with a grain of salt."
2) "I have zero respect for all that "psychology mumbo jumbo"  (your 
words.)"

How you concluded that I claimed to be an expert in all of the fields of 
science baffles me.

Mind you (and you can reread my posts later,) I never expressed anything 
more than my opinion. It was Julie who would use ad hominem arguments and 
was putting words in my mouth.
comments.author: acrh22

comments.text:
+acrh22

Having a PhD in any given field does not make you an expert on everything.
Considering some STEM graduates (the stupid ones; qualifications don't 
necessarily correlate to intelligence) seem to think that a STEM degree 
makes them qualified to asses what is and is not valid within science, your 
claim basically reinforces Julie's position.
comments.author: Dm Gray

comments.text:
+Julie E

I have a PhD in chemistry, and I have zero respect for all that "psychology 
mumbo jumbo"  (your words.)

So kindly, please go educate yourself, and as I said earlier, get on my 
level.
comments.author: acrh22

comments.text:
I said you "lend it no credibility" because you said verbatim,  "Not buying 
that Stanford experiment argument". So I gave you multiple examples 
from qualified scientists, researchers, and universities, which had 
findings consistent with the Stanford Prison Experiment, which you blithely 
ignored.

Who needs to acknowledge evidence when you can just repeat 
yourself? Stanford and Yale must be wrong, because you just don't buy that 
psychology mumbo jumbo. 

Your "level" is pretty consistent with the logical reasoning of a 4th 
grader. Educate yourself before throwing out ignorant statements and 
getting all pissy when proven wrong.
comments.author: Julie E

comments.text:
+Julie E
"You don't dispute the "famous status" of the experiment, but you lend it 
no credibility? Why, because you don't understand it?"

I said no such thing. I said:
"I don't dispute the famous status of the experiment. But psychology 
itself, as a discipline, is so far removed from mainstream physical 
sciences, that I have to take any of its established conclusions with a 
grain of salt."

As a separate question, why do I have to repost an entire earlier post to 
get understanding?

Get on my level.
comments.author: acrh22

comments.text:
You don't dispute the "famous status" of the experiment, but you lend it no 
credibility? Why, because you don't understand it? That's a highly ignorant 
statement, one that perhaps you aren't qualified to make. In 1961 Yale 
University psychologist Stanley Milgram conducted a similar social 
psychology experiment yielding the same results. A human being who has 
neither ability nor expertise to make decisions, especially in a crisis, 
will leave decision making to the group and its hierarchy, consequently 
they no longer see themselves as responsible for their actions, and all 
essential features of obedience will follow. Look up the Milgram 
Experiment, the Asch Conformity Experiments, and the Sheridan & King 
Experiments. All similar experiments, all studies replicating the same 
results - a key factor that clearly satisfies the scientific method.
comments.author: Julie E

comments.text:
+Julie E
I don't dispute the famous status of the experiment. But psychology itself, 
as a discipline, is so far removed from mainstream physical sciences, that 
I have to take any of its established conclusions with a grain of salt.
comments.author: acrh22

comments.text:
The experiment is definitely telling, it cant be denied as proof of the 
power of authority and ideology.
It does not state, however, that EVERYONE turns into an evil sadist.

Some people behave in a sadistic manner.
Some people follow instructions, even if they are immoral.
Some people follow, but express unwillingness, even as they're following.
A minority will speak out.

Remember, it showed prisoners acting with solidarity too (though not always 
or uniformly)
Their role was an inmates, they had nothing to gain and everything to lose 
by refusing to comply, but they could still do so.

It matches my experiences pretty closely.
As a kid a minority of my peers were vicious bullies.
A large section were participants in bullying,
A second (probably largest) were complicit with their inaction. They may 
not contribute, but would never speak out against it.
A tiny minority (smaller than the viscious bully type) would actively 
suppress bullying.

I was bullied, but I believe I fall into the last category.
Perhaps that's ego, but I have always spoken out in defence of others, even 
at personal risk. Maybe if I hadn't been badly bullied, I wouldn't speak 
out as I do.

I believe a majority fall into the middle too categories.
They bully to avoid being targeted, or they refuse to engage at all.
Doesn't make em bad people.
comments.author: Dm Gray

comments.text:
The Stanford Prison experiment is one of the most famous studies in the 
history of psychology, and it's results were definitive. There isn't 
anything to "not buy". 

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_prison_experiment
comments.author: Julie E
